commitResults.messageTitle: Level-1: Add echo feature for Tyrone
Level-2: Add list command and Pair class
Level-3: Add mark/unmark commands using mutable Pair class
Level-4: Made my code more objected oriented, using Task objects
Implemented TyroneExceptionn, and added Asciiart to use in these exception to give chat bot more personality. Done so in a OOP methodology.
Added a text file to read and write to using Tyrone.
Implement Level-8: Add date and time support
Add A-MoreOOP: Extract Ui, Storage, Parser, TaskList classes
Add A-Packages: Organize classes into packages
Add JavaDoc comments to all classes and methods
Add JUnit tests for Tyrone class
refactor: Improve SLAP adherence and refine GUI layout
commitResults.messageBody:
Refactored the codebase to better follow the Single Level of
Abstraction Principle (SLAP) and improved the alignment and
structure of the JavaFX GUI.

Code changes:
- Broke down long methods into smaller helper methods
- Reduced nested logic in processCommand()
- Improved method naming for clarity and intent
- Separated command handling responsibilities

GUI improvements:
- Fixed alignment issues in MainWindow.fxml
- Adjusted spacing and padding for cleaner layout
- Improved consistency of UI component positioning

These changes improve readability, maintainability, and
overall user experience without altering application logic.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add assertions to document key assumptions

commitResults.messageBody:
Tasks with deadlines are not ordered chronologically, making it
difficult for users to prioritize urgent tasks.

Users need to quickly identify which deadlines are approaching to
manage their time effectively.

Let's add a sort command that:
* Sorts all deadline tasks by their date in ascending order
* Uses LocalDate.compareTo() for accurate date comparison
* Maintains relative order for non-deadline tasks

This ensures tasks are displayed from earliest to latest deadline.#

Update PR description with comprehensive GFMD elements

The PR description lacks proper formatting and does not demonstrate
proficiency with GitHub Flavored Markdown, making it less readable
and professional.

A well-formatted PR description helps reviewers understand the changes
quickly and demonstrates proper use of documentation tools that are
essential for collaborative development.

Let's update the PR description to include:
* Multiple heading levels for clear structure
* Bullet lists for features and highlights
* Numbered lists for sequential commands
* Fenced code blocks with Java syntax highlighting
* Task lists to track implementation progress
* Emojis for visual appeal and quick scanning
* Blockquotes for important notes and warnings
* Hyperlinks to relevant documentation
* Inline code for technical terms and commands
* Text formatting (bold, italic, strikethrough) for emphasis

This comprehensive formatting makes the PR more professional and
easier to review, while also demonstrating mastery of GFMD syntax
which is essential for documentation, issue tracking, and code
reviews throughout the project lifecycle.

The description now includes all 10 required GFMD elements as
specified in the task requirements.

commitResults.messageTitle: docs: Add user guide and UI screenshot for GitHub Pages
commitResults.messageBody:
The project lacks published user documentation, making it difficult
for users to understand how to use TYRONE's features.

Users need clear, accessible documentation that explains all commands
and provides visual examples of the application interface.

Let's add:
* Comprehensive user guide (docs/index.md) covering all features
* UI screenshot (docs/Ui.png) showing the application interface
* Command reference table for quick lookup
* Examples for each command with expected output
* FAQ section addressing common questions

This enables GitHub Pages deployment at yishengt.github.io/ip,
providing users with always-available documentation.

The guide uses clear formatting with code blocks, examples, and
tables to make it easy for new users to get started quickly.
